awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  I/UCRC Phase II:  Security and Software Engineering Research Center (S2ERC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Security and Software Engineering Research Center (S2ERC) is an Industry/University Cooperative Research Center devoted to applied and basic research addressing security and software engineering issues that plague both industrial (defense and commercial) companies and government agencies. Nearly all companies market products and services that involve software. The software is either a commercial product or a supporting technology for other products or services. Advances in software engineering are critical to the technical dominance and market performance not only of IT companies, but also of producers of products such as aircraft and their components, automobiles, medical devices, sensors, computer-aided diagnostics and robotics. Software developers and customers desire software that costs less, matches users needs, is secure, has credible defenses and fewer defects, executes faster, is easier to update and is completed on time. With societies growing dependence on software, it is important that software engineers build secure software cost-effectively and reliably.  The investment in S2ERC has the potential to produce significant results given the expertise at the university sites, the many technical affiliate partners, and the importance of software to our national security and competitiveness.  S2ERC researchers are focused on discovering unique solutions for security and software engineering issues which in turn benefits the whole of society as technology is properly constructed and managed.

The S2ERC's technical goals are the creation and transfer of innovative software technologies and engineering skills to its affiliates and the training of both graduate and undergraduate students in promising research directions. The S2ERC research initiatives include intrusion detection, ad-hoc network security, wireless security, attack-tolerant systems, trustworthiness in cloud and mobile applications, security and vulnerability analyses, information protection, requirements capturing, software design, software metrics, software feature analysis, software testing, software reliability, user interface design, usability issues, global software development, migrating software to multi-core architectures, visualization environments, interactive collaborative environments, dynamic and static analyses, and testing and model checking for concurrent programs.  As S2ERC partners with industry and federal agencies, it is expected that security and software engineering research will continue to integrate into broader programs and activities of national interest.

por.por_cntn:
The Security and Software Engineering Research Center (S2ERC) started its Phase II in 2015 with Ball State University being the lead site, and completed its run as an NSF I/UCRC in 2022. During the seven years of Phase II (including two years of no-cost extension), the five university sites (Ball State University, Virginia Tech, Georgetown University, University of Texas at Dallas, and University of Oulu in Finland) worked closely together with 46 affiliates on 78 center-funded research projects, of which 30 were on security, 31 were on software engineering, and 17 were on the intersection of both areas. The projects focused on a variety of research topics addressing cybersecurity, software and system security, and software engineering problems of interest, whose solutions were urgently needed to solve issues that plagued both industrial (defense and commercial) companies and government agencies. Recent S2ERC projects focused on anomaly detection, attack detection, blockchains, code duplication, compiler tools and optimization, cyber data link analysis, data encryption, data protection and privacy, IoT testing, machine learning and deep learning, malicious activity detection and analysis, malware propagation, rigorous specification and testing, secure coding, security policy migration, shared-memory middleware, smart grids, software architecture and design, software assurance, software defined radio, software engineering complexity analysis, software security hardening, threat modeling and detection, vulnerability analysis and remediation, wireless roaming, etc. 

Publications produced as a result of the S2ERC research conducted and/or managed at Ball State University site include 24 journal or juried conference papers and two NSF technological breakthrough compendium publications.

Center-funded research has provided ample opportunities for faculty and students (both ungraduated and graduate students) to work together with industry and government agencies on problems whose solutions have had a real impact on advancing the disciplines. For instance:

RIT researchers developed the new concept of a catalog of common types of architectural weaknesses, called CAWE (Common Architectural Weakness Enumeration), to stimulate security thinking in developers to avoid fundamental design problems in both architectural design and implementation time, and to develop novel techniques to identify and mitigate such flaws. The catalog enumerates 224 architectural weaknesses, documenting how they may affect security tactics. In another project, they expanded and empirically validated NIST's vulnerability description ontology, and developed an automated framework for characterizing vulnerabilities, applying information retrieval and machine learning techniques. They also implemented a solution that searches, extracts and categorizes exploit codes, traces the vulnerabilities to multiple software releases, collects the patches and files affected in source code repositories, and manages the vulnerability life-cycle for each CVE.

BSU researchers looked into how to enhance the identification of code duplications (or clones) that increase the risk of update anomalies and maintenance efforts, and characterize vulnerabilities and fault-prone modules across projects, applying expert, metric and machine learning analysis techniques to uncover indicative vulnerability evidence. In another project, they developed a theory on a simpler, more direct and intuitive derivation of the single use reliability estimate (mean and variance), and applied model-based statistical testing to two real-world testing problems at an affiliate's site. They also looked into the emerging software-defined networking (SDN) paradigm, developing SDN apps following rigorous specification and design methodologies. They developed theory and tool support to automate the migration of security policies to SDN, assuring the migration process does not result in policy violations or security vulnerabilities. Another project at BSU produced a tool to visualize legacy Ada code in an affiliate's codebase in an object-oriented way in fUML, which can be viewed with existing tools such as MagicDraw. BSU/ISU researchers worked on automated software vulnerability detection using natural language processing models assisted by transfer learning, targeting source code written in C/C++ and Java. BSU researchers and educators also developed an educational game about cybersecurity entitled Social Startup Game (available at http://socialstartupgame.info) to teach 10-16-year-olds about cybersecurity and about educational and career paths in cybersecurity. Insight into the impacts of early career choices can help improve educational interventions in cybersecurity and software engineering careers and improve the STEM pipeline. 

At BSU site alone, 10 graduate students and 10 undergraduate students participated in center research. Most of them were hired by the affiliates through internship and/or permanent positions, or by employers who appreciated their research experiences. This valuable experience as well as professional training they received through the center-funded projects undoubtedly played a vital role in both their academic growth and their career development and preparation.
